resource.chars:
13. 
explaining the impossibility of obtaining them. 
Since writing the above I have been informed 
that De Shaw public<s>k<\s>ly suggested that by a "system of 
triangulation" the height of the barrier at our various 
stations could have been determined 'within three 
feet'. 
The report is hearsay and may be inaccurate 
but it must appear that Dr Shaw had some such thought 
in his mind when he wrote the remarks to which I have 
alluded. 
My informant infers that Dr Shaw's triangles 
are vertical and his plan the very simple one of 
comparing the vertical angles of the same mountain at different positions. 
Assuming this to be correct there is no omission 
in our observations; Lieutenant Mulock possesses 
hundreds of angles of elevation of mountains amongst 
the data from which our charts are compiled and would 
gladly place them at Dr Shaw's disposal. 
The question is would these supply the infor-
mation required and the answer is decidedly no. In proof 
of this, one fact alone need be mentioned; the angles 
were obtained by a four-inch theodolite with a vertical 
arc divided to 1', that is, the greatest degree of 
accuracy with which positions could be fixed was one 
<u>mile<\u>
